item.title: Australia Arrests Nurse Who Says He Worked With ISIS Under Duress
item.description: Adam Brookman, who says he was wounded in an airstrike and then forced to work with ISIS, was arrested at the Sydney airport, the Australian police said.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: Turkey Attacks Kurdish Militant Camps in Northern Iraq
item.description: The strikes, which followed Turkish attacks on Islamic State targets in Syria, effectively ended a two-year cease-fire between Turkey and the Kurdistan Workers’ Party.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: In Kenya, Obama Hails Africa’s Growth and Potential
item.description: Declaring that “Africa is on the move,” President Obama on Saturday lauded the economic development that has transformed parts of the continent.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER and MARC SANTORA
item.media:description: President Obama at the Global Entrepreneurship Summit meeting in Nairobi, Kenya, on Saturday.

item.title: Detainees Vanish in Secretive Facilities as Pakistan Fights Taliban
item.description: Dozens have died in military detention amid accounts of torture, starvation and extrajudicial execution from ex-captives, relatives and rights monitors.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: TAHA SIDDIQUI and DECLAN WALSH
item.media:description: Pakistani police officers escorting the wife of a missing person at a demonstration protesting secret detentions in Islamabad, Pakistan, last year.

item.title: U.S. Fears Data Stolen by Chinese Hacker Could Identify Spies
item.description: The potential exposure of the American intelligence officers could prevent a large number of them from being posted abroad again.
item.dc:creator: MARK MAZZETTI and DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: World Briefing: Ukraine: U.S. Expands Aid to Train Regular Army Troops
item.description: The modest expansion of nonlethal military assistance will begin with training this fall for Ukrainian Army personnel in the western part of the country.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW SIDDONS

item.title: World Briefing: Chile: 7 in Pinochet’s Military Charged in Death of Protester
item.description: A judge charged them in the burning death of a 19-year-old American in 1986 during a protest against the dictatorship then in power.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Kerry Says Israel May Deepen Its Isolation by Opposing Iran Nuclear Accord
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry said the deal with Iran was in Israel’s interest, but several foreign policy experts said his remarks risked worsening relations between the countries.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry on Friday at the Council on Foreign Relations in New York to speak about the Iran accord.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Why Greece Should Leave the Eurozone
item.description: The country needs an orderly way to become competitive.
item.dc:creator: HANS-WERNER SINN

item.title: U.S. Says Parole of Jonathan Pollard, Spy for Israel, Will Follow Law
item.description: The White House says relations with Israel will not influence the November release of Mr. Pollard, an American who was convicted of spying for Israel.
item.dc:creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS

item.title: Turkey, Anticipating Attack, Strikes 3 ISIS Targets in Syria With Jets
item.description: The strikes came a day after Turkey’s first reported direct combat with the Islamic State, and its granting of permission to American warplanes to conduct strikes from two of its air bases.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU
item.media:description: A protester in Istanbul on Friday took aim at a police vehicle at a demonstration against an operation attacking Kurdish militants.

item.title: The Effects of Obama’s Presidency in Africa: Readers’ Opinions
item.description: Readers from about a dozen African countries shared their views on President Obama’s time in office, pointing out successes, failures and hopes for the future.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: President Obama talked with President Uhuru Kenyatta of Kenya after arriving in Nairobi on Friday.

item.title: Obama Arrives in Kenya, on Personal and Official Journey
item.description: President Obama emphasized his ties to Kenya, the land of his father, shortly after arriving when he dined with members of his extended family.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER and MARC SANTORA

item.title: Owen Chadwick, Eminent Historian of Christianity, Dies at 99
item.description: “The Reformation” (1964), one of two volumes Professor Chadwick wrote for The Penguin History of the Church, was required reading in colleges for decades.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM GRIMES

item.title: Times Article on Rome’s Decay Draws a Surge of New Scrutiny
item.description: A New York Times article on Romans’ complaints about the decline of the quality of life in their city lit up Italian news media and social networks.
item.dc:creator: GAIA PIANIGIANI
item.media:credit: Nadia Shira Cohen for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rickshaws carrying tourists on the road leading to the Colosseum last week. The mayor of Rome, Ignazio Marino, closed the road to local traffic as soon as he took office, with the idea of creating a pedestrian way.

item.title: Indian Energy Institute Replaces Director Accused of Sexual Harassment
item.description: Rajendra K. Pachauri, the former head of a United Nations panel on climate change, was replaced amid sexual harassment allegations from an employee.
item.dc:creator: NIDA NAJAR
item.media:description: Dr. Rajendra Pachauri was replaced as director-general of the Energy and Resources Institute in India amid accusations of sexual harassment. Earlier, he resigned from the United Nations Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change.

item.title: French Lawmakers Visit Crimea, to the Dismay of Officials Back Home
item.description: The visit to the territory annexed by Russia was condemned by France’s government, but the lawmakers, most of them center-right, said the trip was a private initiative.
item.dc:creator: SABRINA TAVERNISE
item.media:description: Yves Pozzo di Borgo, right, and Jérôme Lambert, members of the French Parliament, at the Siege of Sevastopol Museum in Sevastopol, Crimea, on Friday.

item.title: Egyptians Turn to Facebook to Highlight Decrepit Public Facilities
item.description: Feeling more and more isolated from their government, Egyptians have posted images online to lament the miserable state of their surroundings.
item.dc:creator: KAREEM FAHIM and MERNA THOMAS
item.media:description: A wounded soldier received treatment in January 2013, at an Egyptian hospital. The poor condition of medical and other public facilities in the country have been illustrated on Facebook pages.

item.title: Thailand Charges 72 With Human Trafficking Crimes Ahead of U.S. Report
item.description: The indictments come days before the State Department is expected to release an analysis of international efforts to fight such smuggling networks.
item.dc:creator: POYPITI AMATATHAM

item.title: Burundi President Wins 3rd Term in Election Boycotted by Rivals
item.description: President Pierre Nkurunziza’s bid to retain his office set off street protests, a crackdown, a failed coup attempt and international condemnation.
item.dc:creator: MARC SANTORA
item.media:description: Pierre Claver Ndayicariye, head of the electoral commission in Burundi, announced results on Friday in Bujumbura, the capital. He said that President Pierre Nkurunziza garnered 69.41 percent of the vote.
